channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Rupert Murdoch to Put Media Empire in Sons’ Hands
item.description: Mr. Murdoch put the succession plan in place in March 2014 when he named his sons James and Lachlan to senior positions in his companies.
item.dc:creator: EMILY STEEL and RAVI SOMAIYA
item.media:description: The succession plans for Rupert Murdoch’s media empire have long been the subject of fevered speculation.

item.title: Indian Journalist Who Linked Official to Graft Dies
item.description: Before he died of burns, the journalist, Jagendra Singh, said police officers and associates of a local official had set him afire. The police said they were investigating.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: David Guttenfelder, a Photojournalist, Answers Readers’ Questions on North Korea
item.description: Mr. Guttenfelder has been to North Korea about 40 times. He answers questions on working conditions, local cuisine and American TV.
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The square in front of Pyongyang Railway Station.

item.title: World Briefing: Saudi Arabia: Blogger’s Allies Rebuffed
item.description: Saudi Arabia rejected foreign criticism of the flogging punishment of Raif Badawi, a blogger who has come to symbolize the kingdom’s oppressive restraints on free speech.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: China: Fatal Shooting at Korean Border
item.description: The person was shot after resisting arrest, the government of Helong, a city in China’s northeast, said on its microblog.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Save the Children Group Is Shut Down in Pakistan
item.description: The Pakistani authorities on Thursday shut down the aid group’s office in Islamabad and ordered its foreign staff members to leave the country within 15 days.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Obama Looks at Adding Bases and Troops in Iraq, to Fight ISIS
item.description: The move would require at least hundreds more American military trainers to help Iraqi forces retake cities lost to the Sunni militants.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER, HELENE COOPER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, at a graduation and commissioning ceremony at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., last month.

item.title: A Chinese Ebola Drug Raises Hopes, and Rancor
item.description: The production of an experimental Ebola treatment by a small Chinese company has led to patent infringement claims by American officials and disagreements among doctors.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: The lab at Beijing Mabworks, which developed the experimental drug, MIL77, used to treat Ebola.

item.title: Defying Obama, Many in Congress Press to Arm Ukraine
item.description: The Senate has included provisions in its military policy bill to arm Ukraine with antiarmor systems, mortars, grenade launchers and ammunition to aid in its fight against Russian-backed separatists.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER STEINHAUER and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A woman and her baby on Thursday near their house, which was damaged by shelling in the Ukrainian town of Horlivka.

item.title: I.M.F. Recalls Negotiators as Deadline Looms for Greek Deal
item.description: “Major differences” with the government of Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras were reported as creditors and Athens pursue a deal.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN and LANDON THOMAS Jr.
item.media:description: Alexis Tsipras, the prime minister of Greece, met with European Union officials in Brussels on Thursday.

item.title: Israeli Report Backs Tactics by Military in Gaza War
item.description: Ahead of a U.N. commission report, the Israeli military issued an update on its internal inquiries, saying neither Israeli nor international laws were broken in several deadly clashes.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Zhou Yongkang, Ex-Security Chief in China, Gets Life Sentence for Graft
item.description: Mr. Zhou, the highest-ranking official felled in China’s anticorruption campaign, was tried in secret in the city of Tianjin, the state news media reported.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Syrian Druse Reconsider Alliances After Deadly Attack
item.description: Antigovernment activists said at least 20 Druse were killed on Wednesday night in Idlib Province, fueling fears for civilians and minority sects in the tumultuous region.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Unshaven and Proud: Winners of the Chinese Women’s Armpit Contest
item.description: A women’s rights advocate who organized the contest said she received 46 photos of unshaven armpits during the two-week contest.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO and DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Says It Killed North Korean Suspected of Illegally Crossing Border
item.description: The person was shot early Thursday after resisting arrest in the town of Helong in Jilin Province, the Helong government said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A North Korean soldier patrolling along the border with China. The shooting on Thursday follows a series of violent episodes linked to North Koreans entering China.

item.title: Egyptian Police Officer Convicted in Killing of Activist
item.description: The killing of the activist, Shaimaa el-Sabbagh, in January shocked and captivated Egyptians, because of her evident innocence of any crime.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: In Brazil, Investors Pay a Premium for Tradition
item.description: Brazilians rely on their banks, which dominate the asset-management business and charge mutual fund fees that would shock American investors.
item.dc:creator: DAN HORCH
item.media:description: A Banco do Brasil branch in Rio de Janeiro. A division of the bank, BB DTVM, is Brazil’s largest asset manager.

item.title: Amazon’s E-Books Business Investigated by European Antitrust Regulators
item.description: The investigation is the latest hurdle for Amazon and other American tech giants as European policy makers pursue antitrust, tax and other inquiries.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT and DAVID STREITFELD
item.media:description: Visitors browsing through e-books at a book fair in Frankfurt in 2010. The E.U. is looking into whether Amazon used its dominant position in the region’s e-books market to favor its own products.

item.title: Erdogan Urges Cooperation in Forming New Turkish Government
item.description: The comments from Recep Tayyip Erdogan, Turkey’s president, at a graduation ceremony were striking because they were uncharacteristically conciliatory.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey said at a graduation ceremony on Thursday that "egos should be set aside, and a government should be formed as soon as possible."

item.title: As Supplies Dwindle, World Food Program Cutting Rations to Refugees in Kenya
item.description: The anti-hunger agency of the United Nations said the 30 percent cut, which could last for months, was designed to conserve dwindling supplies and funds.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
